Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Frontiers in the Chemistry of Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Jennifer Brodbelt and colleagues at the University of Texas at Austin host a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site supported by the REU Sites Program of the Chemistry Division. This is an undergraduate research program aimed at interdisciplinary training of future scientific leaders. The projects focus on advanced research in the chemistry of materials, including biomaterials, materials for energy conversion, and the characterization of chemicals and materials. Eight undergraduates from universities around the United States participate in a ten-week summer program that couples intensive training and research-focused mentoring in a way that enhances retention of students in science and engineering. The special emphasis on scientific communication and inclusion of a multi-faceted safety program prepares undergraduates for graduate school or jobs in science, technology and engineering fields. The broader impact of this work is the exposure and involvement of undergraduates, including those from underrepresented groups, to the overarching theme of chemistry of materials and its impact on the world via hands-on training with state-of-the-art spectroscopic, synthetic, and processing techniques.

This program joins chemists and chemical engineers to encompass the discovery, design, development and characterization of new materials. Research efforts in the area of biomaterials draws on integration of concepts related to evaluation of biocompatibility and toxicology, mechanical and structural properties, and ultimately biofunction. The discovery of alternative energy materials represents a critical objectives to alleviate the consequences of relying on carbon-based fuels. One focus is on discovery of more efficient photovoltaic materials, development of catalytic methods for hydrogen production, storage and delivery, and the development of new devices for solar energy capture and conversion. The development of new analytical/physical methods, application of those methods for characterization of biomaterials and energy materials, and assessment of performance metrics are key goals. Some of the undergraduates co-author papers from the emerging research, and faculty engage in mentoring scientists at the earliest stages of their technical development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU Site developed an innovative undergraduate research program aimed at interdisciplinary training of future scientific leaders by joining chemists and chemical engineers to encompass the discovery, design, development and characterization of new materials, including biomaterials, energy materials, and materials characterization. A key facet focused on integrating students after their freshmen years to instill a passion for discovery early in their college programs and enhance the formation of peer networks. Two auxiliary aspects of the program emphasized lab safety and scientific communication. In addition to participation in advanced research projects, students participated in professional development activities that included an interdisciplinary seminar series as well as interactive modules on ethics, career preparation, and public speaking. All participants were housed in a dormitory on-campus to maximize the residential experience and enhance formation of a community of scientists. Participants were selected to enhance the diversity of the peer group, including gender, major, institution, race and ethnicity.  Participants were broadly exposed to the overarching theme of materials science and its impact on our world. They engaged in hands-on training alongside graduate student mentors in state-of-the-art spectroscopic, synthetic, and processing techniques in order to enhance their preparation for graduate school or jobs in STEM fields. A novel feature of the training program was the inclusion of freshmen (rising sophomores) alongside junior-level participants. This delineation between less experienced students and more seasoned students was intended to uncover differences in skill levels, commitment, enthusiasm, and adaptability to new environments. Post-program assessments based on both formative and summative tools indicated that the initially less experienced students performed as well as more experienced students, and there was little perceived difference in technical skill levels of the two groups. This finding was attributed to the fact that advanced research projects, although requiring some basic introductory knowledge, often build upon highly specialized concepts and strategies that do not directly translate from past research experiences. Thus, the personal characteristics of inquisitiveness, persistence, and self-motivation were better predictors of success than academic level and classroom experience. An equally significant finding was the positive acceptance of less experienced participants into research groups. In essence, all research projects required extensive training, and the participant?s level of enthusiasm outweighed the impact of prior experience.
